Chapter 4: Distinguishing and Establishing Karmic Paths, the Meaning of This Should Be Explained.
How many kinds of karmic paths are the volition associated with and arising together with them?
The verse states:
The volition arises together with up to eight evil karmic paths.
The commentary states:

Sometimes the volition arises together with one evil karmic path, apart from the other karmic paths, if greed and so forth arise and manifest, or if a person, with an undeluded mind, causes others to create a karmic path with form in the past, and accomplishes it at one time.
Arising together with two, if a person gives rise to a hateful mind and kills, or if one is defiled by greed and commits theft and sexual misconduct, or speaks inappropriate words.
Arising together with three, if a person gives rise to a hateful mind and kills and steals from other beings at the same time.
If so, at that time, theft is not accomplished due to greed.
If a person's mind is not different, when accomplishing the path of action, one should know the meaning determined before.
If a person is defiled by greed and so on, when accomplishing the two paths of action of body and speech by instructing others,

in this way, if three or four arise together, if a person has the intention to break up the harmony of others, speaking false speech and harsh speech, then one of the paths of action of mind in this case, and three of the paths of action of speech.
Sometimes, defiled by greed and so on, when accomplishing the three separately by instructing others,
the remaining five, six, and seven should be known to be combined in this way.
If eight arise together, in the six cases of instructing others, oneself engaging in sexual misconduct, if they are accomplished together at the same time.
The meaning of the paths of unwholesome action ends here.
The verse states:
If wholesome, up to ten.
The commentary explains:
If discussing the wholesome paths of action that are associated with and not associated with intention, up to the attainment of being associated with ten paths of action.
Having made such a general statement,
In order to distinguish this, a separate explanation is given again.
Verse:
Not shared, one, eight, and five.
Explanation:
The meaning of intention not being associated with the eight or five paths of action.

Here, one associated with two is when the five consciousnesses of good [roots] arise, when entering the formless concentrations, and when the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-production arise.
One associated with three is when the mind associated with right view arises.
One associated with four is when an evil mind or a neutral mind arises, and when receiving the lay devotee precepts and novice monk precepts.
One associated with six is when the five consciousnesses of good [roots] arise, and when receiving the first two precepts.
One associated with seven is when the good mind of consciousness arises, and when receiving the first two precepts.
Or when an evil mind or a neutral mind arises, and when receiving the precepts of a fully ordained monk.
One associated with nine is when the five consciousnesses of good [roots] arise, and when receiving the precepts of a fully ordained monk.

If the mental consciousness is associated with the cognition of exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising, it is the mind associated with the cognition of exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising that is associated with concentration.
That which is associated with ten is different from this, when wholesome mental consciousness arises in other places, and one receives the protection of a bhiká¹£u.

All concentrated protections and uncontaminated protections are associated with intention, apart from the cognition of exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising. If they are not included in the protections, one can also be associated with one.
If a person receives one part of the precepts with a different mind, one can also be associated with five or eight.
If a person, when wholesome mental consciousness arises, receives two parts of the precepts at the same time, or receives five parts of the precepts.
In which path and how many paths of action, whether unwholesome or wholesome, arise simultaneously by manifestation and attainment?
Verse:
Evil speech and harsh speech in hell are two.
Explanation:
These three paths of action exist in hell in two ways:
One is by the presence of the object, the other is by the attainment of the object.
There is frivolous speech by weeping, harsh speech by mutual abuse, and malice by mutual hatred due to the continuity of annoyance.
The verse states:
By attainment, there is sexual misconduct and wrong view.
The commentary states:
If there is sexual misconduct and wrong view by attainment, not by the presence of the object, it is because there are no attractive objects and because they know the fruits of karma.
Because of the exhaustion of karma, there is no killing, and because there is no appropriation of wealth or wives, there is no stealing or sexual misconduct.
Because there is no use, there is no lying, and because they are always unaccompanied, there is no divisive speech.
The verse states:
In the northern continent, there are three.
The commentary states:ğŸ”½By the word attainment, the flow of sexual misconduct, malice, and wrong view is meant.

They are not by the presence of the object, because there is no sense of ownership or appropriation, because the continuity is smooth, because there is no object for the class of malice, and because there is no evil intention.
The verse states:
In the seventh, they have their own.
The explanation is as follows:
The unwholesome actions of speech do not exist there.
Why is this?

Because sometimes those people sing with a defiled mind, but without evil intent, because there is no killing, etc., because their lifespan is fixed, because they do not possess wealth or wives, and because there is no need for them.
How do those people engage in sexual misconduct?ğŸ”½If those people wish to unite with a woman, they take her hand and go together to the foot of a tree.
If the woman is suitable for intercourse, the tree immediately covers them, and they engage in sexual activity.
If she is not suitable, the tree does not cover them, and they go away from each other.
The verse states:
In the other realms, there are ten unwholesome actions.
The explanation is as follows:
There is a tradition of saying this.
Except for hell and the northern continent, in the other realms, the ten kinds of unwholesome courses of action exist by way of manifestation as well.
Among the realms of animals, hungry ghosts, and gods, there are unwholesome courses of action that are not unwholesome by nature.
Among the human realm, the unwholesome courses of action that are included in the unwholesome by nature also exist.
If a god cannot kill other gods, they can kill beings of other destinies.
If the gods cut off the head or waist of another god, they immediately lose their lives.
The evil karmic paths have been explained.
A verse says:
The last three exist in all realms, because they are obtained through manifestation.
The explanation is as follows:
Non-greed, non-hatred, and right view exist in all five destinies and three realms, both through manifestation and through obtainment.
A verse says:
In the formless realm and among the non-percipient celestials, there are seven through obtainment.
The explanation is as follows:
The seven good karmic paths of body and speech exist in the formless realm and among the non-percipient celestials only through obtainment.
Because the noble ones who have already been born in the formless realm are associated with the past and future uncontaminated precepts through obtainment.

The non-percipient celestials are associated with the obtainment of the meditative precepts, according to the stage on which they depend. The uncontaminated precepts that the noble ones are born in and abandon.
If one is born in the formless realm, one is associated with this past restraint, and also associated with the future restraint based on the five stages.
Verse:
The rest also exist through manifestation, except in hell and in the northern continent.
Explanation:
The rest refers to other realms and other paths.
In the other realms and other paths, these seven kinds of good courses of action also exist through manifestation, except in hell and in the northern continent.
The rest refers to animals and ghosts, in which there is only non-restraint.
In the form realm, there is only restraint, but in the other places, both exist.
Next, as for these ten evil courses of action and good courses of action, verse:
All are able to give dominant, outflow, and retribution fruits.
Explanation:
Now, let us discuss evil.
Because of cultivating and frequently engaging in all ten evils, one is born in hell, which is called the retribution fruit.
If one has already experienced the retribution of hell, one obtains this kind of class, namely the homogeneous character of the human realm, etc. Due to killing, one has a short lifespan;
Due to stealing, one has obstacles to wealth;
Due to sexual misconduct, one has many enemies and obstacles to wives and concubines;
Due to false speech, one is often slandered;
Due to divisive speech, one's close friends are not harmonious;
Due to harsh speech, one always hears unpleasant sounds;
Due to idle chatter, one's reasonable and true words are not believed;ğŸ”½Due to covetousness, one has heavy covetousness;
Due to ill-will, one has heavy ill-will;
Due to wrong views, one is dark and dull with much delusion.
This view is mostly due to ignorance, and this is called the result of the outflow of the ten unwholesome deeds.
If the lifespan in the human realm is short, it is also the result of wholesome karma.
How is this the result of the outflow of killing, etc.?
It is not said that the lifespan of humans is the result of the outflow.
What are they?
Due to evil karma, the lifespan is reduced.
Killing is the cause of obstacles to the lifespan in the human path, this meaning should be understood.
As for the dominant fruit, due to the cultivation and frequent occurrence of the matters related to killing,
all external resources and living necessities lose their vitality and flavor. Due to stealing, there are many lightning strikes and dust;ğŸ”½due to sexual misconduct, there is much dust and dirt;
due to false speech, there is much foul odor;
due to divisive speech, the external environment has high and low;
due to harsh speech, the ground has an unpleasant taste, with high and dry conditions unsuitable for everything;
due to idle chatter, the seasons are not comfortable, and the four elements change unevenly;
due to greed, all planted fruits have little strength;
due to hatred, all that is born is full of suffering;
due to wrong views, all resources may have few fruits or no fruits. This is called the dominant fruit of the ten evil deeds.
Is it by this action that one has a short life in the present existence, or by another action?
Some say:
It is by this action.
Why?
Because at that time the action had the effect of retribution, now it has the effect of equal outflow.
Some say:
At that time it was the preliminary stage, now it is the fundamental stage. Because it is said to be accompanied by grasping.
The effect of equal outflow of killing, etc., is not of the same kind, but is said to be so because of similarity and distinction.
Moreover, how do the ten courses of action have three kinds of effects?
When a person commits killing, because of the suffering produced in the one who is killed, because of the cutting off of their life, and because of the destruction of their vigor and vitality.
Therefore, it is said in the verse:ğŸ”½By affliction, cutting off life, and destroying vigor and vitality, there are three effects.
Because of afflicting others, there is the effect of retribution, because in hell one experiences affliction.
Because of killing, there is an equal flow result, now being born with a beloved short life.
Because of reducing the power and taste of others, there is an enhanced result, the power and taste of external herbs and medicines are either non-existent or weak.
The remaining karmic paths should also be understood to have three results in the same way.
The three results of good karmic paths should also be understood in the same way.
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, said:
There is wrong speech, wrong action, and wrong livelihood.
What is wrong livelihood that is different from these two?
There is no difference from these two.
The verse states:
Bodily and verbal actions born from greed are separately established as wrong livelihood.
The commentary states:
If bodily and verbal actions born from anger and delusion towards sentient beings are called wrong speech and wrong action, they are established separately from these two as wrong livelihood.
The verse states:
Difficult to cure.
The commentary states:

The dharmas of greed universally attract sentient beings. Therefore, the mind that gives rise to actions from them is difficult to restrain and protect. Therefore, right livelihood is difficult to cure.
In order to generate deep respect in others, these two are established as the third [pÄrÄjika].
Here, a verse is spoken:
At home, wrong views are difficult to cure, always grasping various views;
For bhiká¹£us, life is difficult to cure, because their livelihood depends on others.
A verse says:
If one grasps, it arises from greed.
The commentary says:
If a person grasps at the requisites for life, the bodily and verbal actions born from greed are called wrong livelihood, not the others.
Why is this?
For one's own amusement, dancing and singing, etc. are not established as requisites for life.
A verse says:
Because it is not in the sÅ«tras.
The commentary says:
This is not so.
Why is this?
Because of the sÅ«tra's statement:
In the SÅ«tra on the Aggregate of Morality, the Buddha established watching elephant fights, etc. as wrong livelihood.
Why is this?
Because of wrongly enjoying objects.
This topic is concluded.
First, among the five fruits previously mentioned, by how many fruits is each of the actions fruitional?
The verse states:
Actions with outflows have five fruits in the path of cessation.
The path is cultivated for the sake of attaining cessation, and because defilements are extinguished through this path, it is called the path of cessation, referring to the uninterrupted path.
The actions that exist in this path with outflows have five kinds of fruits as results.
Why is this?
The desirable fruits obtained in one's own stage by this action are called the fruits of retribution.
The similar dharmas that appear later, whether equal or superior, are the fruits of the same outflow.
The fruit of separation refers to the mind's separation from the bonds through discrimination.

The fruit of efficacy refers to the dharmas produced by the path, namely the path of liberation and the dharmas co-arisen with it, the other dharmas that should be obtained in the future, and this discrimination.
The dominant fruit refers to the conditioned dharmas other than one's own nature, excluding those arisen previously.
Verse:
In the undefiled, by four.
Explanation:
In the undefiled cessation and path, karma has four fruits, excluding the fruit of separation.
Verse:
In the defiled, the rest, good and bad.
Explanation:
If good defiled karma is different from cessation and path, and if bad karma is different from cessation and path, these two have four fruits, excluding the fruit of disconnection.
Verse:
The rest, undefiled karma, by three; so is neutral.
Explanation:
All undefiled karma, if different from cessation and path, and if neutral karma, by three fruits, excluding the fruit of retribution and the fruit of disconnection.
Verse:
Four, two, and the rest three; the fruit of good karma is good, etc.
Explanation:
This meaning should be understood in order, and will be explained later.
Sometimes good karma has good dharmas as its fruit, then it has four fruits, excluding the fruit of retribution.
If it takes unwholesome dharmas as its effect, then it has two effects, namely the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
If it takes indeterminate dharmas as its effect, then it has three effects, excluding the homogeneous effect and the disjunction effect.
Verse:
If unwholesome and wholesome, etc., are two, three, and four in order.
Explanation:
This meaning should be understood in order.
If unwholesome karma takes wholesome dharmas as its effect, then it has two effects, namely the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
If it takes unwholesome dharmas as its effect, then it has three effects, excluding the retributive effect and the disjunction effect.
If it takes indeterminate dharmas as its effect, then it has four effects, excluding the disjunction effect.
What is the homogeneous effect?
It refers to the indeterminate view of self and extreme view, which are the homogeneous effects of the unwholesome universal defilements eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering.
Verse:
Indeterminate has two, three, and three again in relation to wholesome, etc.
Explanation:
If non-defined action has wholesome dharmas as its effect, then it has two effects: the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
If it has unwholesome dharmas as its effect, then it has three effects: excluding the effect of retribution and the effect of disjunction.
How is this so?
Unwholesome defilements to be eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering are the effect of similar outflow of the two non-defined views.
If it has non-defined dharmas as its effect, then it has three effects.
The verse states:
All past [actions] have four [effects].
The commentary states:
All refers to dharmas of the three times.
If these dharmas are the effect of past actions, each has four effects, excluding the effect of disjunction.
The verse states:
The effect of present [actions] is the same as that of future [actions].
The commentary states:
If present actions have future dharmas as their effect, then they have four effects, as before.
The verse states:
The effect of present [actions] is two [effects].
The commentary states:
If present dharmas are the effect of present karma, there are only two effects: the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
The verse states:
Future karma has three effects in the future.
The explanation states:
If future karma has future dharmas as its effect, then there are three effects, excluding the homogeneous effect and the disconnection effect.
The verse states:
Dharmas of the same stage have four.
The explanation states:
Excluding the disconnection effect, the remaining effects are all present.
The verse states:
Three and two if in different stages.
The explanation states:
If karma in different stages is without outflows, then there are three effects, excluding the retribution effect and the disconnection effect, because it does not fall into the realms.
If it has outflows, then there are two effects, namely the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
The verse states:
Learned ones have three, learners, etc.
The explanation states:
If learned karma has learned dharmas as its effect, then there are three effects, excluding the retribution effect and the disconnection effect.
If it takes the dharmas of no-more-learning as its effect, it is the same.
If it takes the dharmas of neither learning nor no-more-learning as its effect, then it has three effects, excluding the effect of retribution and the effect of similar outflow.
The verse states:
The dharmas of learning, etc., and the dharmas of no-more-learning have only one effect, or three effects, and two effects.
The commentary states:
If the karma of no-more-learning takes the dharmas of learning as its effect, then it has one effect, which is the dominant effect.
If it takes the dharmas of no-more-learning as its effect, then it has three effects, excluding the effect of retribution and the effect of disjunction.
If it takes the dharmas of neither learning nor no-more-learning as its effect, then it has two effects, which are the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
The verse states:
The two and five effects of the other two, learning, etc.
The commentary states:
The karma that is neither learning nor no-more-learning, if it takes the dharmas of learning as its effect, then it has two effects, which are the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
The same applies to taking the non-learner dharmas as fruits.
If one takes the neither-learner-nor-non-learner dharmas as fruits, then there are five fruits.
The verse states:
Three, four, and one fruit, and the seen-extinguished karma and their equals.
The commentary states:
If seen-extinguished karma takes the seen-extinguished dharmas as fruits, then there are three fruits, excluding the retribution fruit and the disjunction fruit.
If it takes the cultivated-extinguished dharmas as fruits, then there are four fruits, excluding the disjunction fruit.
If it takes the non-extinguished dharmas as fruits, then there is one fruit, namely the dominant fruit.
The verse states:
Two fruits, four, and three, the cultivated-extinguished karma.
The commentary states:
If the cultivated-extinguished karma takes the seen-extinguished dharmas as fruits, then there are two fruits, namely the effort fruit and the dominant fruit.
If it takes the cultivated-extinguished dharmas as fruits, then there are four fruits, excluding the disjunction fruit.
If non-extinguishable dharmas are taken as its effect, then it has three effects, excluding the effect of human effort and the similar effect.
Verse:
Non-extinguishable karma has one, two, and four effects in order.
Explanation:
If non-extinguishable karma takes the dharmas extinguished by seeing the truth as its effect, then it has one effect, which is the dominant effect.
If it takes the dharmas extinguished by cultivation as its effect, then it has two effects, which are the effect of human effort and the dominant effect.
If it takes non-extinguishable dharmas as its effect, then it has four effects, excluding the effect of retribution.

The phrase in order is used again. It should be understood that the various meanings are explained again in the beginning, middle, and end, in order to clarify the meaning of the characteristics of karma.
The characteristics of this karma should also be asked about.
In the Abhidharma Piá¹­aka, it is said that there are three kinds of karma: improper action, proper action, and neither improper nor proper action.
What are the characteristics of this karma?
Verse:
Some say that unwholesome action is that which is done with defilement, others that it is that which is not in accord with the rules.
The explanation is as follows:
Some say that action done with defilement is unwholesome, because it arises from incorrect thought.
Other masters say:
Action that is not in accord with the rules of proper conduct is unwholesome.

If a person should act in this way, should live in this way, should eat in this way, should wear clothes in this way, and so on, if one does not act in accordance with this, it is called unwholesome action.
This action is called unwholesome because it is done in a manner that is not in accord with reason.
All wholesome action is called wholesome.
And that which does not lose the rules of proper conduct is also called wholesome.
Action that is neither of these two is called neither wholesome nor unwholesome action.
Does one action project one birth, or does one action project many births?
Moreover, are many actions projected by one birth, or is one birth projected by one action?
If one explains the doctrine in this way, it should be said as follows.
A verse [is stated]:
One action projects one birth.
The explanation is:
Only one birth is projected by one action, and it cannot project many births.
Birth is the name of the aggregate of similar types. If one obtains that, it is called birth.
If so, how did the Venerable Aniruddha say:

Now, as a result of the offering of one meal in the past, I was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three for seven times, became a wheel-turning king for seven times, and now I was born in the greatly wealthy ÅšÄkya family.
By this karmic retribution, he obtained the fruit of great wealth and the ability to remember past lives, and further produced separate karma.
In order to show its function, this statement was made.
It is like a person who, by the power of one gold coin, obtains a thousand gold coins, and then says this:
Now, because of one gold coin, I have become greatly wealthy.
It is also said that this person, based on the offering of a meal at that time, had the longest and greatest continuity of mental intentions.
Among these, there are various intentions that can attract and accumulate retribution.

One cannot say that many karmas produce one birth, lest each part attract a collection of the same type, and this collection of the same type is attracted by one karma, while the others are allowed to be different.
The verse says:
Many karmas can perfect it.
The explanation is:
For example, a painter uses one color to sketch the human form and many colors to perfect it.
Why is this?

In the world, there are sentient beings who have the same human nature and the same human form, but some have complete faculties, body parts, complexion, appearance, size, strength, and uprightness, and are most distinct and lovable in the human realm.
Some others are incomplete in these aspects. It is not only karma that can attract birth.
What are the other dharmas with retribution?
If all kinds, the verse says:
The two meditative absorptions cannot attract, being without mind and attainment.
The explanation is:
The two mindless samÄdhis also have retribution, but they cannot attract and gather the same kind of existence, because they do not arise together with karma.
Attainment is also like this, because it has a different result from karma.
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, said:
There are three kinds of obstacles, namely the obstacle of karma, the obstacle of afflictions, and the obstacle of retribution.
What is the essential nature of these three obstacles?
A verse says:
The heavy karma of the five heinous crimes, the afflictions that remain, the evil destinies, Uttarakuru, and the non-percipient celestials are said to be the three obstacles.
The commentary says:
The five heinous crimes and so forth are called the obstacle of karma.
Namely, killing one's mother, killing one's father, killing an arhat, causing a schism in the Saá¹…gha, and maliciously drawing blood from a TathÄgata - these are called the obstacle of karma.
The afflictions that remain are called the obstacle of afflictions.
Afflictions are of two kinds:
First, remaining, which refers to constant activity;
Second, intense, which refers to heavy categories.
Here, the afflictions that are the cause of defiled abiding are called the affliction obstacle, like eunuchs, etc. Afflictions that are strong and sharp are not obstacles.
Why is this?
If afflictions are strong and sharp due to being of a heavy class, sometimes they arise and are not constant, so sometimes they can be eliminated.
Afflictions of a light class are always active.
Why is this?

If afflictions are always active and to be eliminated, when one does not have the opportunity to cultivate, these afflictions become of a medium class based on a light class, and based on a medium class become a heavy class.
These afflictions are the correct obstacles.
The three kinds of evil destinies are called the retribution obstacle, and a part of the good destinies is also so, namely the people of Uttarakuru and the non-percipient devas.
What does this triple obstacle obstruct?
It obstructs the noble path and the wholesome roots that are the preparation for the noble path.

There are also other actions whose retribution is definite in the evil destinies, etc., namely definite rebirth in an egg-born or moisture-born existence, rebirth in a female body, and rebirth in the eighth existence. It should also be said to be an obstacle of action.
If an action can be understood and explained through these five causes, that action is established as an obstacle.
What are the five?
First, by basis; second, by fruit; third, by path; fourth, by birth; fifth, by person. Therefore, only five are mentioned.
Among them, the obstacle of afflictions is the coarsest, and the obstacle of karma is the next coarsest.
Why is this?
Because of these two, in the second life, this person cannot be cured.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Because they can ride one after another, they are explained in sequence.
What is the meaning of uninterrupted?
In the arising of karmic retribution, there is no other karma or other birth that can obstruct it.
Furthermore, the person who commits this karma, if they abandon their life, will be born in the hell of karmic retribution without interruption, and nothing can hinder it.
Because this person is associated with this dharma and is born in hell without interruption, it is called uninterrupted, like a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Furthermore, these three kinds of obstacles should be known to exist in which path?
If it is definite, the verse states:
In the three continents, without interval.
The explanation is as follows:
In the northern continent and other paths, it does not exist, let alone in other realms.
Among humans, only men and women can commit this karma.
The verse states:
Eunuchs and so on are not allowed.
The explanation is as follows:
What is the reason that they do not have it?
The cause of protection is precisely this cause.
There is another cause, the verse states:
Little kindness and little shame.
The explanation is as follows:
In order, parents have little kindness towards a certain child, and that child has little shame towards his parents.
Parents have little kindness towards a certain child because his body is incomplete and they love him less.
That child has little heavy shame towards his parents. By breaking this shame, he is touched by the uninterrupted offense.
For this reason, the uninterrupted karma is not allowed to exist in the animal and ghost realms.
The Venerable One says:
If one's wisdom is clear, there are five immediate [karmas], like a clever horse.
If one kills a non-human or one's parents, there is no immediate [karma].
The karmic hindrances have been explained.
A verse says:
The other hindrances are in the five paths.
The commentary says:
What are the other [hindrances]?
They are the hindrance of afflictions and the hindrance of karmic retribution.
The hindrance of karmic retribution means that in the human realm, the people of Uttarakuru, and in the heavenly realm, the asuras.
What is the essence of these immediate [karmas]?

Four are bodily actions as their essence, one is verbal action as its essence, three are killing as their nature, one is lying as its nature, and one is the preliminary stage of killing as its nature.
The Buddhas and TathÄgatas cannot be killed, but the Dharma is established as the result of the cause, so it is said that the schism of the harmonious Saá¹…gha is an immediate [karma].
Because the Saá¹…gha is split by this cause, the cause is given the name of splitting.
What is the meaning of this splitting?
A verse says:
The schism of the Saá¹…gha is not a united state, and is not a dharma associated with the mind, nor is it a defiled or indeterminate dharma.
The explanation is as follows:
A united state refers to a dharma that is not associated with the mind, is indeterminate, and is not a concealing [dharma]. A schism of the Saá¹…gha is also like this.
How can this [schism] become an uninterrupted [karma]?
The person who causes the schism is not associated with this [schism]. Why is it so?
The verse says:
The Saá¹…gha is associated with this.
The explanation is as follows:
Why is it so?
Because the schism belongs to those who are being split, not to the one who causes the schism.
If that is so, with what dharma is the one who causes the schism associated?
The verse says:
Based on this lie, the one who causes the schism is associated with it.
The explanation is as follows:
The one who causes the schism is associated with the sin of causing the schism of the Saá¹…gha. This sin is a lie.

If a person wishes to know the characteristics of the lightness and heaviness of various karmas, in brief it should be known that there are six causes.
The verse says:
The latter part, the field, and the basis, the former part, the intention and vow, because of being inferior and superior, therefore karma has inferiority and superiority.
The explanation says:
The latter part means that having done this karma, one further repeatedly follows and does it.
The field is the place where harm and benefit are practiced.
The basis refers to the path of karma.
The former part means that in order to attain the path of karma, the intention of body and speech, if by this the path of karma is completed.
Intention means thinking in this way and that way, I should do this and that, and thinking in this way and that way, I am doing this and that.
Wish means seeking future use.
Some people, due to belonging to the latter part, accomplish heavy karma, because the retribution is definitely established.
Moreover, some people, due to belonging to the field, accomplish heavy karma. Due to belonging to the basis in the field, this karma becomes heavy, not due to other causes.
The basis refers to the path of karma, such as parents and other beings.
Due to the heaviness of the basis of killing, not due to the heaviness of stealing, etc., the rest should be understood in the same way.
If a person performs karma, and all of these six causes are all of the highest grade, one should know that this karma is of the heaviest grade.
If a person performs karma, and all of these six causes are all of the lowest grade, one should know that this karma is of the lightest grade.
It is said in the sutra:
Karma is of two kinds: that which is done and that which is cultivated.
How is karma cultivated?
For five reasons.
The verse says:
By intention, completion, absence of regret and counteraction, by companions, and by fruition, karma is said to be increased.
The commentary says:
How is it by intentional action?
This karma is intentionally done, not without prior intention, not done in haste, but after careful consideration and choice.
How is it by completion?
Some people fall into evil realms by one wrong action, some up to three.
Some people fall into evil realms by one karmic path, up to some by ten.

Here, if a person should fall into evil realms by this amount of karma, if that amount is not yet complete, this karma is only what is done, not what is increased. If it is already complete, then it is what is increased.
How is it by absence of regret and counteraction?
If a person performs karma without regret in it, and does not accept good conduct as a counteraction.
How is it by companions?
Delusion causes evil, and evil becomes one's companions.
How is it by retribution?
This karma is already able to give retribution.
Good karma should also be considered in the same way.
If it is different from this characteristic, the karma done is only done, not long-lasting.
It has been said before that a person who has not yet eliminated desire and gives things to a caitya, this giving is only for one's own benefit and not for the benefit of others.
If there is no one who can enjoy the given things in this case, how does this karma become merit?
Meritorious karma is of two kinds:
One is the type of abandonment, if this meritorious karma arises from giving up things;
The other is the type of enjoyment, if this meritorious karma arises from enjoying the given things.
A verse in this regard says:
Merit of the type of abandonment towards a caitya.
The commentary says:
In this case there is no merit of the type of enjoyment.
If they do not enjoy it, how can there be merit?
What is the evidence?
If there is one who can receive, there is necessarily merit. If there is none who can receive, then there is no merit, because there is no benefit for even one.
This reason is not established as evidence.
Why is this?

If merit is due to benefiting others, then cultivating the immeasurables such as loving-kindness and right view should be without merit. Therefore, it should be accepted that in the case of merit towards a caitya, only abandonment is the type.
The verse says:
Just like loving-kindness, even if not received.
The commentary says:
Just as in the contemplation of loving-kindness and compassion, even though there is no one who can receive or benefit others, immeasurable merit arises from one's own mind.
In the same way, if one respectfully serves a virtuous person who has passed away, the merit that arises from one's own mind.
In that case, the karma of giving respect and so on should be without result.
This is not so.
Why is this?
Because the karma that arises takes the respectful mind as its supreme condition.

For example, a person wants to kill an enemy, but the enemy has already died. This person still thinks of the enemy and gives rise to the intention, creating bodily and verbal actions, producing much demerit, not merely by the intention to kill.

In the same way, when the Great Teacher has already passed away, if someone out of a respectful attitude gives rise to respect and makes offerings, etc., the most merit is produced, not merely by the respectful attitude.
If one practices giving and giving rise to respect, etc. in a good field, one obtains a desirable reward.
If in a bad field, one should obtain an undesirable reward.

Correctly accomplished means produced by right skillful means.

Number, if produced by superior skillful means, belongs to mental actions and also arises together with conditions, and has the four aggregates as its nature. This number is precisely mental activity.

Nirvana is the escape from all dharmas of birth and death, and is therefore called liberation.
This dharma is unequaled by any other dharma.

Because it is good, true, and eternal.
